com.sri.ai.grinder.sgdpllt.api

Interface Constraint

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable<java.lang.Object>, Expression, java.io.Serializable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Context, SingleVariableConstraint
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractConstraint, AbstractSingleVariableConstraint, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithBinaryAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithBinaryAtomsIncludingEquality, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithDependentNormalizedAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithIndependentNormalizedAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableNumericConstraint, CompleteMultiVariableContext, DefaultMultiVariableConstraint, MultiVariableContextWithCheckedProperty, SingleVariableConstraintForTheoryWithoutAtoms, SingleVariableDifferenceArithmeticConstraint, SingleVariableEqualityConstraint, SingleVariableLinearRealArithmeticConstraint, SingleVariablePropositionalConstraint, TrueContext

    public interface Constraint
extends Expression
    An Expression with efficient internal representation for satisfiability. As of August 2016, only implementations are conjunctive clauses, but eventually it should be expanded to arbitrary formulas.
    Author:
    braz

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Expression binding(Expression variable)
      Returns an expression to which the given variable is bound to under this constraint, if there is such a value and it can be determined by the implementation.
      default Constraint conjoin(Expression formula, Context context)
      Returns an SGDPLLTTester representing the conjunction of this constraint and a given formula, or null if they are contradictory.
      default Constraint conjoinWithConjunctiveClause(Expression conjunctiveClause, Context context)
      Returns the result of conjoining this constraint with all literal conjuncts of a given conjunctive clause (note that if conjunction is not an application of and, it will be considered a unit conjunction with itself the only conjunct.

      Returns an SGDPLLTTester representing the conjunction of this constraint and a given literal, or null if they are contradictory.

      default boolean isValidConjoinant(Expression formula, Context context) 
      Constraint makeContradiction()
      Make contradictory version of this constraint; this means the contradiction is of the same "type" as this contradiction (for example, same theory, among other details), but is a contradiction.

    • Method Detail

      • getTheory

        Theory getTheory()
        Returns the general theory used in the application. TODO This method should probably be eliminated. It used to be "the constraint's theory", but that meaning got blurred when compound constraint theories got introduced, because then the application theory could be a compound theory, whereas a single-variable constraint could be specific to just one of the sub-constraint theories. This caused problems because throughout the code we rely on this method to obtain the application's theory; when dealing with a single-variable constraint, this would instead give us its specific sub-theory. We changed it by making the method hold the general application theory even for single-variable constraints. This solved the problem but rendered the method misleading, since it does not represent a property of the constraint itself. It is now just a convenience method that spares us the trouble of passing the theory everywhere but, like stated above, at the cost of being misleading.
        Returns:
        the application's theory.

      • conjoinWithLiteral

        Constraint conjoinWithLiteral(Expression literal,
                              Context context)
        Returns an SGDPLLTTester representing the conjunction of this constraint and a given literal, or null if they are contradictory.

        At this point, the formula should be either a literal, or a Constraint.

        Parameters:
        literal - the literal to be conjoined.
        context - the context
        Returns:
        the application result or null if contradiction.

      • conjoin

        default Constraint conjoin(Expression formula,
                           Context context)
        Returns an SGDPLLTTester representing the conjunction of this constraint and a given formula, or null if they are contradictory.

        At this point, the formula should be either a literal, or a Constraint.

        Extensions may want to override this method if there are more efficient ways of conjoining with (certain types of) constraints than simply treating them as a formula

        Parameters:
        formula - the formula to be conjoined.
        context - the context
        Returns:
        the application result or null if contradiction.

      • isContradiction

        default boolean isContradiction(Expression formula)
        Tests whether an expression is a contradiction (that is, equal to false), by first checking if it is a Constraint and using isContradiction(), and only if that fails, using equals(FALSE). This avoids the unnecessary generation of an Expression form for Constraints that only make it under demand.
        Parameters:
        formula -
        Returns:

        Parameters:

        context -
        Returns:
        the result of conjoining this constraint with all conjuncts of a given conjunction

        Expression binding(Expression variable)
        Returns an expression to which the given variable is bound to under this constraint, if there is such a value and it can be determined by the implementation.
